statement: $\exists\ c>0\ \text{absolute s.t.}\ \forall n\ge2:\ \theta(n)\ \ge\ c\,\frac{n^{2}}{2^{n}},\ \text{and moreover }\exists\ L\subset\mathbb R^{n},\ r>0:\ \Delta(L,r)\ge c\,\frac{n^{2}}{2^{n}}.$

(Siegel mean value) Let $S\subset\mathbb R^n$ be bounded measurable and $D>0$. Averaging over unimodular lattices of covolume $D$ gives $\mathbb{E}_L\,\#\{v\in L\setminus\{0\}:v\in S\}=\dfrac{\mathrm{vol}_n(S)}{D}$ and $\mathbb{E}_L\,\#\{v\in L\text{ primitive}:v\in S\}=\dfrac{\mathrm{vol}_n(S)}{D\,\zeta(n)}$.
(Cohn–Elkies LP bound) Linear programming methods yield upper bounds on $\theta(n)$ that are best known in many dimensions (e.g. $4\le n\le36$).
(Cohn–Zhao) The Kabatiansky–Levenshtein upper bound is improved by an absolute constant factor, and the Cohn–Elkies LP bound is always at least as strong as the KL bound.
(Three-point bounds) Semidefinite-programming three-point bounds sharpen linear-programming upper bounds, improving $\theta(n)$ upper bounds for $n\in\{4,5,6,7,9,\dots,16\}$.

(Historical context of $n\,2^{-n}$ order) Statistical-physics methods (hard-sphere model) give another proof that for large $n$ there exist packings of density $\Omega\!\bigl(n\,2^{-n}\bigr)$, consistent with Rogers–Davenport–Ball bounds.
